Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Mobile Visual Search Engine
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will develop a biologically-inspired image search and recognition technology to provide rapid object information retrieval from a mobile phone camera. The end result is that potentially any object in the real world is now "clickable": a picture of an object provides a hyperlink to the Internet. The proposed system utilizes a new method for sparse, multi-scale image representation based on the monogenic signal, a 2D generalization of the analytic signal that is robust to image transformations.

By 2010, it is estimated that there will be over 1 billion mobile phones with cameras.The mobile phone is becoming an important connection between people and the digital world. The applications for mobile search technology are enormous and include national homeland security, product information retrieval (such as environmental ratings, pricing, or specifications), vision support for the blind, accessing object information for the disabled, and general purpose information retrieval including remote visual data analysis and inspection. Search technology has brought about many profound societal, educational and scientific benefits in the past decade. The proposed mobile image search technology will extend those benefits to a broader base of users and applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcome: IQ Engines developed the underlying technology for three critical components of the company’s VisionIQ image recognition software: (1) software development kits (SDKs) for mobile phone app development, (2) an open application programming interface (API) for accessing cloud-based image recognition capabilities, and (3) a crowdsourcing service that uses human taggers to identify images when automated computer vision techniques cannot.

IQ Engines makes this technology available to retailers, media companies and mobile app developers who are using VisionIQ to power visual search, shopping, content discovery and other apps. For more on customer use cases see: https://www.iqengines.com/applications/

Intellectual Merit: IQ Engines tackles one of the biggest challenges in computer science today -- how to make computers see the world around them. Key technological advances made during the course of the NSF funded Phase IIB project include:

  1. Developing a hybrid image recognition engine combining computer vision, crowdsourcing and machine learning that paves the way for future advances in all three fields.
  2. Advancing techniques for large-scale image recognition processing by making the VisionIQ platform faster, more accurate, and less expensive per query.
  3. Increasing the percentage of images that can be recognized with computer vision by developing a classification system capable of searching new types of image content.
  4. Developing innovative collaborative human computation algorithms and leveraging the existing integration of human computation by creating learning algorithms that train computer vision systems from the data generated by human taggers.
  5. Extending the system architecture to support these advances by providing the infrastructure needed to commercialize an open API.

Broader Impact: IQ Engines believes image recognition is a disruptive technology that will enhance the way people find information and interact with the world using their camera phones, as well as enabling completely novel modes of interaction, myriad applications and unforeseen benefits. To encourage the innovation needed to bring this vision to fruition, IQ Engines has taken steps to make the technology broadly available through an open API that provides partners, customers, and users with unprecedented access to automated image intelligence. By putting this leading edge image labeling engine in the hands of everyone from hobbyists to large corporations, IQ Engines hopes to make visual search tools increasingly valuable as a means of processing the enormous volume of unlabeled images produced every day.

Modified by: Gerald A Pesavento
